expanded_description: This culminating project brings together everything you've learned about systems of equations and inequalities. You'll tackle a realistic business scenario that requires defining variables, setting up constraints, graphing systems, and using linear programming to find optimal solutions. The project emphasizes real-world decision-making, interpretation of results, and clear communication of findings.

core_concept.principle: Real-world projects require: (1) Understanding the problem context and identifying key variables. (2) Translating constraints into mathematical inequalities. (3) Graphing the feasible region. (4) Finding corner points. (5) Optimizing an objective function. (6) Interpreting results in context and making recommendations. (7) Communicating findings clearly.
core_concept.explanation: Think of this project as running your own business consulting firm. You've been hired to help a company make better decisions. You'll analyze their constraints, find the best possible outcomes, and present your recommendations. This is where math meets the real world—your solutions will have practical consequences.

sections.introduction: You are a consultant hired by a furniture factory to help optimize their production. The factory produces two types of products: chairs and tables.

introduction_image.alt: Furniture factory with chairs and tables
introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.9.2: The furniture factory scenario.

key_concept.definition: **The Scenario:** A small furniture factory produces chairs and tables. They have contacted you to help them determine the optimal production mix to maximize profit, given constraints on labor, materials, and demand.
key_concept.context: This project will walk you through the entire process of mathematical modeling, from understanding the problem to presenting your recommendations.

worked_examples.title: Project Data
worked_examples.problem:
The factory has provided the following data:

| Resource | Per Chair | Per Table | Available |
|----------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| Labor (hours) | 2 | 3 | 240 hours/week |
| Wood (units) | 1 | 2 | 180 units/week |
| Profit | $\$40$ | $\$50$ | |

Additionally, due to market demand, they must produce at least 20 chairs and at least 15 tables per week. They cannot produce more than 60 chairs due to space limitations.

step_by_step.explanation: Let $x$ = number of chairs produced per week, $y$ = number of tables produced per week

worked_examples.final_answer:
Variables: $x$ = chairs, $y$ = tables
Constraints: $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y \leq 240 \\ x + 2y \leq 180 \\ x \geq 20 \\ y \geq 15 \\ x \leq 60 \end{cases}$
Objective: Maximize $P = 40x + 50y$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Translate the problem data into mathematical form.

sections.introduction: The first step is to graph all constraints to visualize the feasible region.

key_concept.definition: Graph each constraint inequality on the same coordinate plane. Use different colors or patterns for each. The feasible region is where all constraints are satisfied simultaneously.
key_concept.context: A clear, accurate graph is essential for identifying corner points.

worked_examples.title: Graphing All Constraints
worked_examples.problem: Graph all constraints from the furniture factory problem on a single coordinate plane.

step_by_step.explanation: Vertical line at $x=20$, shade to the right.
Vertical line at $x=60$, shade to the left.
The overlap of all constraints is the feasible region.

worked_examples.final_answer: Feasible region is the polygon where all constraints overlap, bounded by $x=20$, $x=60$, $y=15$, and the two slanted lines.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Graph each constraint carefully and identify the overlap.

sections.introduction: The optimal solution will occur at a corner point of the feasible region. Find all intersection points.

key_concept.definition: Corner points are intersections of constraint boundaries. Solve systems of equations for each pair of boundary lines, then check if the point satisfies all constraints.
key_concept.context: In this problem, we have multiple constraints, so there will be several corner points to find.

worked_examples.title: Finding All Corner Points
worked_examples.problem: Find all corner points of the feasible region from the furniture factory problem.

step_by_step.calculation: Check if it satisfies other constraints: $2(20)+3(15)=40+45=85\leq240$, $20+2(15)=20+30=50\leq180$. Yes, feasible.
$(20,66.67)$ - check wood: $20+2(66.67)=20+133.33=153.33\leq180$ yes. Also check $x\leq60$ and $y\geq15$ satisfied.
$(20,80)$ - check labor: $2(20)+3(80)=40+240=280>240$, violates labor. So not feasible.
$(60,60)$ - check labor: $2(60)+3(60)=120+180=300>240$, violates labor. Not feasible.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Find all intersections, then check feasibility against all constraints.

sections.introduction: Now evaluate the profit function at each corner point to find the maximum profit.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.9.20: Calculate profit at each corner.

key_concept.definition: Substitute each corner point into the objective function $P = 40x + 50y$. The point that gives the highest value is the optimal production plan.
key_concept.context: In linear programming, the optimal solution for a maximization problem is always at a corner point.

image.alt: Table of corner points with profit
image.caption: Figure 8.9.21: Profit calculations.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Profit at Each Corner

image.caption: Figure 8.9.22: Evaluate profit at each corner.

worked_examples.problem: Calculate the profit $P = 40x + 50y$ at each feasible corner point found in Step 2.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Evaluate the objective function at each corner point.

sections.introduction: The mathematical solution must be interpreted in the context of the real-world problem.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.9.24: Making sense of the numbers.

key_concept.definition: The optimal solution $(60,40)$ gives the highest profit, but we must consider practical issues: Can we produce fractional chairs? Are there storage limitations? Does the market demand match this production mix?
key_concept.context: Real-world decisions often require adjusting mathematical optima to account for practical constraints.

worked_examples.title: Interpreting the Optimal Solution
worked_examples.problem:
Based on the results, answer the following:
a) What is the optimal production plan?
b) What is the maximum weekly profit?
c) Are all constraints binding at the optimum?
d) What would you recommend to the factory?

step_by_step.calculation: Produce 60 chairs and 40 tables per week

step_by_step.explanation: At $(60,40)$, labor: $2(60)+3(40)=120+120=240$, exactly at limit; wood: $60+2(40)=60+80=140\leq180$, not binding; $x=60$ is at maximum, so chair limit binding; $y=40$ is above minimum 15, not binding.
step_by_step.calculation: Labor and chair maximum are binding; wood and minimums are not.

step_by_step.explanation: Recommend producing 60 chairs and 40 tables weekly for maximum profit of $\$4400$. Note that this uses all available labor and the maximum chair capacity. Consider whether increasing chair capacity could lead to higher profits.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) 60 chairs, 40 tables; b) $\$4400$/week; c) Labor and chair max binding; d) Adopt this plan.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Interpret mathematical results in the business context.

sections.introduction: Sensitivity analysis explores how changes in constraints or profits would affect the optimal solution.

key_concept.definition:
Sensitivity analysis asks questions like:
• How much would profit change if we could increase labor?
• What if the profit per chair increased?
• What if the minimum chair requirement changed?
• How sensitive is our solution to changes in constraints?
key_concept.context: Real-world decisions often involve uncertainty. Sensitivity analysis helps prepare for different scenarios.

worked_examples.title: Exploring What-If Scenarios
worked_examples.problem:
Answer the following sensitivity questions:
a) If labor could be increased to 250 hours, would the optimal solution change?
b) If the profit per table increased to $\$60$, would the optimal solution change?
c) If the minimum chair requirement increased to 30, would the optimal solution change?

step_by_step.explanation: At current optimum (60,40), labor used is 240. With 250 hours, we might be able to increase production. The binding constraints would shift, potentially allowing a new optimum.
step_by_step.calculation: We would need to re-solve with new labor constraint $2x+3y\leq250$ to find new optimum.
Now (20,66.67) and (60,40) tie at 4800. Multiple optimal solutions exist.

step_by_step.explanation: New constraint $x \geq 30$. Check current optimum (60,40) still satisfies. Need to check if new corner points appear at intersection of $x=30$ with other constraints.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Possibly; b) Multiple optima; c) Current optimum still best.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Sensitivity analysis explores how changes affect the optimal solution.

sections.introduction: Your final project should include several components that demonstrate your understanding and communicate your recommendations.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.9.32: What to include in your project.

key_concept.definition:
Your project should include:
1. **Problem restatement** in your own words.
2. **Variable definitions** and explanation.
3. **Complete system of constraints** and objective function.
4. **Graph** of the feasible region with all constraints and corner points labeled.
5. **Corner point calculations** shown step by step.
6. **Objective evaluation** at each corner point.
7. **Optimal solution** and interpretation.
8. **Sensitivity analysis** for at least two scenarios.
9. **Recommendations** to the factory management.
10. **Reflection** on the process and limitations.
key_concept.context: A well-organized, clearly explained project demonstrates mastery of the concepts.

worked_examples.title: Sample Executive Summary
worked_examples.problem: Write a brief executive summary of your findings and recommendations.

step_by_step.explanation: After analyzing the furniture factory's production constraints, we have determined that the optimal production plan is to manufacture 60 chairs and 40 tables per week. This plan utilizes all available labor hours and respects the maximum chair capacity, while leaving some wood resources unused. The projected weekly profit is $\$4,400$. Sensitivity analysis shows that increasing labor hours could potentially increase profits, while changes in table profit could create alternative optimal solutions. We recommend adopting this production plan and monitoring labor efficiency closely.

sections.introduction: For extra challenge, consider these additional scenarios or variations of the problem.

key_concept.definition:
Extension ideas:
• Add a third product (e.g., stools) with its own resource requirements and profit.
• Introduce a storage constraint (total volume of products).
• Consider seasonal demand fluctuations.
• Include a labor overtime option at higher cost.
• Add a quality constraint (ratio of chairs to tables).
key_concept.context: Real problems are rarely as simple as textbook examples. Extensions help prepare for real-world complexity.

worked_examples.title: Extension: Adding a Third Product

image.caption: Figure 8.9.38: Add stools to the product line.

worked_examples.problem: Suppose the factory can also produce stools. Each stool requires 1 hour of labor and 1 unit of wood, and gives a profit of $\$25$. How would you modify the problem? What new considerations arise?

step_by_step.explanation: Let $z$ = number of stools produced per week
This becomes a 3-variable problem. Graphing is no longer possible; we would need algebraic methods (simplex method) or technology.

worked_examples.final_answer: Three-variable LP problem requiring advanced methods.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Real problems often have more than two variables, requiring more sophisticated techniques.

summary: This real-world project applies all the concepts from systems of equations and inequalities to a practical business scenario. The process involves: understanding the problem, defining variables, translating constraints into inequalities, graphing the feasible region, finding corner points, evaluating the objective function, interpreting results, and making recommendations. Sensitivity analysis explores how changes in constraints or profits would affect the optimal solution. The final project deliverables include a complete mathematical analysis and a clear executive summary communicating findings to management. This project demonstrates the power of mathematical modeling in real-world decision-making and prepares students for using algebra in business, economics, and operations research. Extensions show how problems can grow in complexity, highlighting the need for more advanced techniques in real applications.
